[Free operations and states]\label{def:free} 
We define the set of free operations as a unitary representation $R$ of a compact group $G$, i.e., $R:G\rightarrow \mathbb{GL}(\HC)$, with  $\mathbb{GL}(\HC)$ the general linear group over $\HC$. Then, the set of pure free states is obtained as the orbit of some reference state $\ket{\psi_{\rm ref }}$ under $R(G)$, i.e., all free states take the form $R(g)\ket{\psi_{\rm ref }}$ for some $g\in G$.

[Purity in the algebra is a resourcefulness witness, Theorem in~\cite{barnum2004subsystem}]\label{theo:algebra-purity}
    Let $\PC_{\mathbb{C}R(\mathfrak{g})}(\rho)$ be the purity of a state $\rho=\dya{\psi}$ onto the irrep $\mathbb{C}R(\mathfrak{g})$ of $\LC(\HC)$. Then, $\PC_{\mathbb{C}R(\mathfrak{g})}(\rho)$ is maximized iff $\ket{\psi}$ is a free state.
